module_title: Topic 1: The Board's Mandate: ESG as a Value Driver | Topic 2: Deconstructing Fragmentation: Overcoming Reporting Challenges | MORNING TEA BREAK
submodule_title:
• Why sustainability reporting is essential for competitive advantage and long-term value creation.
• Navigating evolving investor, regulatory, and customer expectations.
• Defining "integrated value": Beyond financial metrics to holistic impact and resilience.
• Mini Case Study: A leading global asset manager, facing pressure from institutional investors, divested from a major energy company due to its lagging climate transition plan and poor governance scores. This move, publicly cited by the fund, triggered a significant stock price dip for the energy firm, underscoring the direct financial consequence of perceived ESG underperformance and the board's accountability | • Identifying common pain points: Siloed data, fragmented efforts, and a lack of cohesive narrative.
• The tangible costs of missed synergies and incomplete organizational understanding.
• Interactive discussion: Pinpointing your organization's specific challenges and strategic aspirations.
• Mini Case Study: A global retail giant struggled for years with inconsistent carbon emissions data. Each regional operations team used different methodologies and reporting tools, making it impossible for the central Sustainability team to aggregate accurate, comparable figures. This fragmentation led to missed reduction targets and a lack of credibility in their public disclosures, ultimately hindering their ability to secure green financing.

module_title: Topic 3: Global Benchmarks & Strategic Frameworks for Impact | LUNCH BREAK
submodule_title:
• Overview of leading sustainability reporting frameworks (e.g., GRI, SASB, TCFD, ISSB, ESRS) –
• focusing on strategic alignment and value creation, not just compliance.
• Mastering "materiality": Identifying the ESG issues that truly matter to your business and its stakeholders.
• Case studies: Analyzing best-in-class sustainability reports and their measurable impact.
• Mini Case Study: A global software company initially used GRI for broad impact reporting, but found it didn't fully resonate with tech-focused investors. By integrating SASB standards, they sharpened their focus on industry-specific material issues like data privacy, employee diversity in tech roles, and energy consumption of data centers, leading to more targeted and impactful investor engagement.

module_title: Topic 4: Building a Robust Data Architecture for Sustainability Reporting | AFTERNOON TEA BREAK | Topic 5: Crafting a Strategic Narrative: Beyond the Numbers | Q&A and Day 1 Wrap-up
submodule_title:
• Identifying critical ESG data points across diverse functions (e.g., operational emissions, supply chain labor practices, diversity metrics, climate-related financial risks).
• Strategies for robust data collection, validation, and aggregation, emphasizing accuracy and traceability.
• Addressing data quality, consistency, and governance challenges.
• Workshop: Mapping key data sources and flows within your organization, identifying critical integration points.
• Mini Case Study: An automotive manufacturer successfully implemented a new data architecture by integrating real-time energy consumption data from its production lines (Business Operations) with supply chain emissions data from its tier-1 suppliers (Procurement). This unified system, managed by Finance for cost allocation and Sustainability for reporting, provided a granular view of their Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions, enabling precise carbon reduction strategies. | • Principles of effective storytelling in corporate reporting: Connecting purpose, strategy, and measurable performance. Translating complex data into clear, actionable insights for diverse audiences (investors, customers, employees, regulators).
• Techniques for articulating your organization's unique impact and value creation journey.
• Interactive exercise: Developing a compelling narrative arc for a critical sustainability theme.
• Mini Case Study: A major food and beverage company transformed its water stewardship narrative. Instead of just reporting cubic meters of water saved, their sustainability report highlighted how their water efficiency programs in water-stressed regions directly supported local community resilience, improved agricultural yields for their suppliers, and secured long-term access to critical resources, resonating strongly with both ethical consumers and impact investors. | • Key strategic insights and preparation for Day 2's focus on operationalizing collaboration.

module_title: Topic 6: Principles of High-Performing Cross-Functional Teams | Topic 7: Introduction to the RACI Matrix for Sustainability Reporting | MORNING TEA BREAK
submodule_title:
• Breaking down organizational silos: Fostering shared objectives, mutual understanding, and collective ownership.
• Establishing effective communication channels and protocols for seamless sustainability reporting.
• Cultivating a common language and unified vision for ESG performance.
• Mini Case Study: A global pharmaceutical company faced a complex ethical sourcing challenge for a new drug component. A dedicated cross-functional task force, comprising R&D, Legal, Procurement, and Sustainability, established clear communication protocols and shared objectives from the outset. This enabled them to navigate intricate regulatory landscapes and secure sustainable, ethical supply chains, preventing significant reputational and operational risks. | • Understanding R (Responsible), A (Accountable), C (Consulted), I (Informed) in the context of complex, multi-stakeholder reporting processes.
• Why RACI is critical for clarity, efficiency, and robust accountability in sustainability reporting.

module_title: Topic 8: Applying RACI: Defining Clear Roles & Responsibilities | LUNCH BREAK
submodule_title:
• Interactive Session: Participants will work in cross-functional groups to apply the RACI framework to core sustainability reporting processes.
• Discussion of common pitfalls, mitigation strategies, and best practices in RACI implementation for sustained collaboration.
• Mini Case Study: A large financial services firm struggled to collect comprehensive Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) data for its annual report. Without a clearly defined RACI, the HR team felt solely responsible for data collection, while Finance and Legal only provided input reactively. This led to significant delays and blame-shifting. Implementing a clear RACI, with HR as "Responsible," the Head of People as "Accountable," and Finance/Legal as "Consulted" for data definitions, streamlined the process significantly in the following year.

module_title: Topic 9: Streamlining the Sustainability Reporting Lifecycle | Topic 10: Assurance, Verification & Enhancing Credibility | AFTERNOON TEA BREAK | Topic 11: Future-Proofing Your Reporting & Strategic Action Planning | Course Wrap-up & Next Steps
submodule_title:
• Process optimization: Identifying bottlenecks and opportunities for efficiency across data flows and content creation.
• Leveraging technology and digital tools for enhanced data management, aggregation, and reporting automation.
• Strategies for seamlessly integrating sustainability data into existing financial, operational, and HR systems.
• Mini Case Study: A major energy utility implemented a new digital platform to automate the collection of energy consumption data from its smart grid infrastructure (Business Operations). This platform seamlessly integrated with the Finance department's billing systems and provided real-time sustainability dashboards for management, drastically reducing manual data entry errors and accelerating quarterly ESG reporting cycles. | • The critical role of external assurance in bolstering report credibility and stakeholder trust.
• Preparing for assurance: Establishing robust internal controls, comprehensive documentation, and data readiness.
• Navigating and adapting to evolving regulatory landscapes and mandatory disclosure requirements.
• Mini Case Study: A leading consumer goods company faced public scrutiny from environmental NGOs regarding its deforestation-free palm oil commitments. Despite internal reports, skepticism persisted. Only after undergoing a rigorous, independent third-party assurance process, which meticulously verified their supply chain data and practices, did the company regain full stakeholder trust and silence its critics, demonstrating the power of external validation. | • Emerging trends in ESG data, artificial intelligence, and digital reporting innovations.
• Developing a phased roadmap for continuous improvement in sustainability reporting capabilities.
• Group Exercise: Crafting a concrete, collaborative action plan for immediate implementation within your organization.
• Mini Case Study: A global technology firm is piloting an AI-powered analytics tool that scans vast datasets of social media, news, and customer feedback to identify emerging ESG risks (e.g., labor unrest in a new market, supply chain disruptions due to climate events). This proactive intelligence informs their sustainability strategy, risk management, and future reporting disclosures, allowing them to adapt faster than competitors. | • Consolidating key takeaways and fostering a commitment to collaborative action.
• Providing resources for ongoing learning, peer networking, and sustained support.

submodule_title:

 Issues Addressed: 
 An employer will know how to classify or define when a staff’s conduct is legally regarded as a disciplinary offence — even if the Employee Handbook or Collective Agreement does not list such conduct as a punishable offence.

module_title: Session 2: Disciplinary Process  | AFTERNOON TEA BREAK | Session 2: Disciplinary Process (continued)
submodule_title:
a) General disciplinary process 
 i) Preliminary investigation 
 ii) Show Cause Letter 
 iii) Punishment 
 b) Investigative suspension 
 i) Salary cut
 ii) Extended suspension
 Issues Addressed:
 An employer will know how to classify or define when a staff’s conduct is legally regarded as a disciplinary offence — even if the Employee Handbook or Collective Agreement does not list such conduct as a punishable offence.
 An employer will learn what to do when an employee goes against instructions or commits misconduct — whether minor (e.g. lateness) or major (e.g. disrespect) — and the proper way to impose punishment, including dismissal.
 An employer can ensure that staff are deterred from committing even minor acts of misconduct. |  a) General disciplinary process 
 i) Preliminary investigation 
 ii) Show Cause Letter 
 iii) Punishment 
 b) Investigative suspension 
 i) Salary cut
 ii) Extended suspension

module_title: Session 3: Handling Sick Leave Issues  | MORNING TEA BREAK
submodule_title:
a) Sick Leave basic rules
 i) Calendar Year eligibility 
 ii) Sick Leave and Hospitalisation. 
 b) MC basic rules 
 i) When Sick Leave becomes Absenteeism 
 ii) Valid MC Prerequisites 
 c) Popular Sick Leave Related Misconduct 
 i) Malingering 
 ii) Forged or Amended MC 
 iii) Excessive or Frequent MC
  
 Issues Addressed:
 An employer will be able to identify whether a medical certificate (MC) is lawfully valid and recognize situations where an MC can be lawfully rejected.
 An employer will learn how to handle frequent or excessive MC or emergency leave (EL), especially those taken adjacent to rest days or public holidays, and how to take appropriate action, including dismissal, where necessary.

module_title: Key 2022/2025 Amendments: | LUNCH BREAK
submodule_title:
o Expansion to cover all employees—removal of wage ceiling for coverage
o Protection for gig workers and flexible/remote work arrangements
o Increase in minimum wage (e.g., RM1,700 as of 2025)
o Increase in maternity leave (98 days), addition of paternity leave, prohibition on dismissal of pregnant employees
o Reduction in max weekly working hours (now 45 hours)
o New rules for overtime, paid parental leave, and social security
o Employer obligations regarding contracts, complaint channels, and dispute resolution procedures

o Forms: Verbal, non-verbal, visual, psychological, and physical harassment | • Tribunal for Anti-Sexual Harassment: Role, process, and remedies (compensation up to RM250,000; final, binding decisions)

o Mandatory policies, reporting procedures, awareness campaigns, and investigation guidelines

A. The Six Goals of Technical Writing 
Precision 
Using accurate terminology
Avoiding ambiguity 
Clarity 
Explaining complex information in simple terms
Structuring information logically
Forthrightness 
Stating facts and instructions directly
Avoiding unnecessary disclaimer 
Familiarity 
Matching language complexity to audience level
Using familiar examples and analogies 
Conciseness 
Eliminating unnecessary words and phrases
Focusing on the key message
Fluidity 
Maintaining a smooth writing style
Using transitions for clear flow

module_title: Session 1: The Sustainability Imperative & Regulatory Landscape | MORNING TEA BREAK
submodule_title:
• Welcome & Program Overview: Setting the stage for two days of intensive learning.
• Global to Local: The Urgency of ESG in Malaysia:
o Global and industry-specific trends in sustainability, including regulatory changes and stakeholder expectations. Differentiate various sustainability reporting frameworks such as GRI, SASB, CDP, TCFD, TNFD, ISSB IFRS, EU CSRD, and US SEC
o Drivers for enhanced ESG reporting: Investor expectations (local and international), key regulatory landscape, supply chain pressures, talent attraction, and financial implications.
o Malaysia's commitment to sustainability: National policies, UN SDGs, and the shift towards a low-carbon economy.
• Bursa Malaysia's Enhanced Sustainability Reporting Framework:
o In-depth analysis of Main Market and ACE Market Listing Requirements: Current mandatory disclosures, phased implementation for Group 1 and Group 2 PLCs.
o Key changes and expectations: Common Sustainability Matters, three-year performance data, and the journey towards assurance.
o Practical Example: Dissecting a recent Bursa Malaysia Circular on Sustainability Reporting amendments.
• Securities Commission Malaysia's Role in SRI and Governance:
o The Sustainable and Responsible Investment (SRI) Roadmap: How it impacts corporate practices and investor engagement.
o Malaysian Code on Corporate Governance (MCCG) and ESG Integration: Board oversight, accountability, and the link between governance and sustainability performance.
• Case Study 1: Navigating Early Adoption – A Malaysian PLC's Journey with Bursa Requirements. (Interactive discussion on challenges and successes based on an anonymous Malaysian company's recent sustainability statement).

module_title: Session 2: Laying the Foundation – ISSB Standards | LUNCH BREAK
submodule_title:
• Introduction to the IFRS Sustainability Disclosure Standards (ISSB):
o Purpose, objectives, and global acceptance of IFRS S1 and IFRS S2.
o The "climate-first" approach and the role of the National Sustainability Reporting Framework (NSRF) in Malaysia's adoption with limited transition.
o Understanding the building blocks: Governance, Strategy, Risk Management, and Metrics & Targets.
• IFRS S1 – General Requirements for Disclosure of Sustainability-related Financial Information:
o Conceptual Deep Dive: Core content requirements, reporting entity, material sustainability-related financial information.
o Practical Application: Identifying material sustainability matters using the ISSB lens and local context.
o Case Study 2: Materiality Assessment for a Malaysian PLC. Participants will work in groups to identify and prioritize material ESG issues for a hypothetical Malaysian company (e.g., a manufacturing company or a property developer) considering local environmental and social sensitivities.
• IFRS S2 – Climate-related Disclosures: The Core Climate Standard:
o Detailed review of climate-related disclosure requirements across the four pillars.
o Understanding physical and transition risks and opportunities relevant to Malaysian industries (e.g., impact of climate change on agriculture, palm oil, tourism, manufacturing supply chains).

module_title: Session 3: Bridging Frameworks & Governance Practicalities | AFTERNOON TEA BREAK | Session 4: Strategy and Financial Implications
submodule_title:
• Interoperability: ISSB, GRI, and TCFD in the Malaysian Context:
o Key differences and overlaps: How to leverage existing GRI and TCFD reporting efforts to meet ISSB requirements.
o Conducting a practical Gap Analysis: Identifying current disclosure gaps and developing an action plan for ISSB compliance.
o Case Study 3a: Bridging the Divide – A Malaysian Conglomerate's Approach to Integrating Multiple Frameworks. Analysis of a listed company's sustainability report, identifying how they align or distinguish between different reporting standards.
• Governance Pillar: Board Oversight and Internal Controls for ESG:
o Establishing effective governance structures: Board committees, management roles, and accountability for ESG.
o Integrating ESG into existing enterprise risk management (ERM) frameworks.
o Case Study 3b: PLC’s governance platforms to manage sustainability – examples at listed multinationals and corporations. Developing an ESG governance structure. Participants will map out an ideal ESG governance structure for their organization, considering local corporate governance best practices. | • Strategy Pillar: Linking Sustainability to Business Resilience:
o Identifying and assessing sustainability-related risks and opportunities: Focus on Malaysian-specific scenarios (e.g., water scarcity, labor practices in specific sectors, renewable energy opportunities).
o Integrating ESG into strategic planning and capital allocation decisions.
o Case Study 4: Current and Anticipated Financial Effects of Sustainability Risks and Opportunities.
▪ Quantifying Financial Impacts. Using provided data scenarios (e.g., carbon tax impact, supply chain disruptions, green financing benefits), participants will estimate potential financial effects for PLCs in group discussions.

module_title: Session 5: Climate Disclosure and Scenario Analysis | MORNING TEA BREAK
submodule_title:
• Metrics & Targets Pillar: Focus on Climate-Related Metrics:
o Comprehensive GHG Emissions Accounting (Scope 1, 2, & 3): Methodologies, data collection challenges in Malaysia (e.g., supply chain data for Scope 3).
o Setting meaningful and ambitious climate targets: SBTi (Science Based Targets initiative) and alignment with Malaysia's Net Zero ambitions.
• Deep Dive 2: Climate Scenario Analysis for Malaysian PLCs.
o Understanding different climate scenarios (e.g., IEA NZE, RCPs): Relevance to Malaysian industries.
o Practical Steps for Conducting Scenario Analysis: Data requirements, analytical tools, and interpreting results.
o Hands-on Exercise 3: Simplified Climate Scenario Analysis Application. Participants will work through a simplified climate scenario for a Malaysian industry (e.g., real estate, financial services, or manufacturing), identifying potential impacts and strategic responses.
• Case Study 5: A Malaysian Bank's Approach to Climate Risk Integration and Scenario Analysis. Discussion on how financial institutions are responding to BNM's climate risk management expectations. Or, Financial Institutions in managing climate-to-credit risks.

module_title: Session 6: Risk Management and Data Integrity | LUNCH BREAK
submodule_title:
• Risk Management Pillar: Identifying, Assessing, and Managing Sustainability Risks:
o Integrating sustainability risks into enterprise-wide risk management (ERM) frameworks.
o Emerging ESG risks relevant to Malaysia: Biodiversity loss, human rights in supply chains, cyber security and data privacy.
o Workshop: ESG Risk Matrix Development. Participants will develop a preliminary ESG risk matrix for their organization, categorizing and prioritizing risks.
• Data Management for Robust ESG Reporting:
o Establishing robust internal controls for ESG data: Collection, aggregation, quality checks, and audit trails.
o Leveraging tech solutions: ESG software, data analytics, and reporting platforms.
o Addressing data challenges common in Malaysia: Data availability, consistency, and fragmentation across departments.
• Case Study 6: Data Journey of a Malaysian Utility Company for ESG Reporting. Insights into data collection processes, challenges, and solutions adopted.

module_title: Session 7: Crafting the Report & Assurance Readiness | AFTERNOON TEA BREAK | Session 8: Implementation Roadmaps & Future Trends
submodule_title:
• Crafting a Compliant and Impactful Sustainability Statement:
o Structure and content of an ISSB-aligned sustainability report.
o Best practices in clear, concise, and balanced disclosure.
o Narrative reporting vs. quantitative data: Achieving the right balance.
o Illustrative Sustainability Report: Utilizing the forthcoming Malaysian illustrative report (based on GRI and ISSB) as a practical guide.
• The Evolving Landscape of Assurance for Sustainability Statements in Malaysia:
o Bursa Malaysia's stance on assurance: Current recommendations and future outlook.
o Understanding different levels of assurance (limited vs. reasonable).
o Preparing for assurance readiness: Documentation, internal controls, and engaging with assurers.
o An overview of ISSA 5000 (International Standard on Sustainability Assurance 5000) developed by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB), and the connection with the ISSB IFRS S1/S2 reporting.
o Case Study 7: Common challenges faced by Malaysian PLCs in seeking assurance and how to overcome them. | • Developing a Phased Implementation Roadmap for ISSB Adoption:
o Prioritizing actions and resource allocation.
o Stakeholder engagement strategy for ESG reporting.
o Internal communication and capacity building within the organization (PACE initiative).
• Beyond Compliance: Value Creation through ESG:
o Linking strong ESG performance to access to sustainable finance (SRI Sukuk, green loans).
o Enhancing reputation, attracting talent, and fostering innovation.
• Future Trends and Emerging Areas in ESG Reporting for Malaysia:
o Nature-related financial disclosures (TNFD).
o The role of AI and digitalization in ESG.
• Case Study 8: Artificial Intelligence and Water Stress: A global tech company's AI data center in a drought-prone region drew public backlash after excessive water use for cooling exacerbated local water scarcity, harming communities and ecosystems amid limited transparency and accountability.
• Concluding Remarks & Open Forum: Final Q&A, sharing of best practices, and next steps for continuous improvement in ESG reporting.

module_title: Session 2: Handling of fire extinguishers | Lunch Break
submodule_title: Practice the PASS technique: Pull the pin, Aim the nozzle at the base of the fire, Squeeze the handle, and Sweep side to side. Conduct regular inspections and maintenance checks on fire extinguishers to ensure they are in working condition. Understand the limitations of fire extinguishers and know when it is safe to attempt to extinguish a fire or when to evacuate.

module_title: Quick PRE-TEST. | PME 1: INTEGRATION | MORNING TEA BREAK
submodule_title:
Project Life Cycle for instance construction starts from Origin i.e 
Inception/Concept to Design (Architectural & Engineering) followed by Procurement and Construction & finalized by Commissioning/Testing for Completion or Hand Over to Client. In some cases, for construction, it may include Earthworks at the beginning for unsuitable type of soil at location.

Project consist of various types based on different Contract coverage. Common types are Design Conventional Project, Turnkey Project, EPCC as mentioned above (Engineering-Procurement-Construction & Commissioning) etc. along with their project life cycle accordingly. For the last few decades, also found new types has embarked predominantly known as Design and Build Fast Track Project, which Contractor plays the role from start to finish with consultant act as advisor and care taker for the Client.
 | Oversees all the project undertaking requirements without flaw from start to end. It is responsibilities of the PM - Project Manager ensuring project executed in accordance to the PME 1 - 9 with HSE + 5S as the principle & policies. Seven (7) Habits of Successful People will be used as guidance in practicing the integrity project management.

module_title: PME 2: SCOPE | PME 3: TIME | PME 4: COST (CAPEX AND OPEX) | LUNCH BREAK
submodule_title:
Identify the content and limits of the project for any sectors mentioned above. WBS - Work Breakdown Structures is recommended to define Scope by itemizing the deliverable/product hierarchically. Understanding Scope is fundamental throughout project from Start to End for issues either Technical or Commercial on Contracts, Variations, Claims, Supplementary Agreement, Liquidated Damages - LD, Reimbursable or Ex-Gratia for win-win result amicably. WBS can be used for project ‘GO’ or’ ‘NO GO’ initially especially during the tender/bidding stage by reviewing the Technical Application and Commercial Requirement for Feasibility and Viability Analysis respectively. If company has no experience in the technology required e.g. IoT/AI so it is a NO GO. Similarly, if company cannot afford the financial implied, also it is NO GO. WBS is the key to elaborate all the main parameters of projects as per the Triple Constraint:
1. Time by Planning/Scheduling which can also incorporate CPM - Critical Path Method manually or via software
2. Costing via BOM (Bill of Materials) & BOQ (Bill of Quantity)
3. Quality referring to Standards/Specifications as imposed. | As per Scope above, Time also driven by the project activities dominantly by Predecessor and Successor. Team member - has to understand the activities sequence in their profession in meeting the goal timely.
The 4 key formats are;
1. Start to Finish
2. Start to Start
3. Finish to Finish
4. Finish to Start
Progress as per Actual vs Plan as reference to the Based Project Plan is crucial to avoid EOT (Extension of Time) which will impact negatively to the company.

 | Cost is driven by 5Ms i.e.
1. Materials
2. Machines & tools
3. Manpower competency
4. Methodology
5. Monetary exchange (if foreign exchange applies) ROI (Return On Investment) vs Break-Even Analysis will also be presented for optimum profits.

module_title: PME 5: QUALITY | AFTERNOON TEA BREAK | PME 6: HUMAN RESOURCE - HR (MANPOWER COMPETENCIES) | PME 7: COMMUNICATIONS | Q & A
submodule_title:
Quality Standards as per QMS - Quality Management System requirements will be presented incorporating ISO standards based on the deliverables/products.
Apart from HSE + 5S, Quality adherence nowadays must also comply to ESG - Environmental, Social & Governance.
Selected Quality ethics will be discussed namely JIT - Just in Time, Jidoka, Gemba, Lean & Lean Six Sigma and Kaizen.
Advance Related Topics for Discussion:
1. Lean for reduce time
2. JIT - Just in Time to minimize Wastage (Stock / Warehouse / Inventory).
Both above will lead to Lean Six Sigma I.e. Zero Defects Target. | Manpower and with the right & adequate competencies are critical for project success. As above these will cover the KSA mentioned. The project team organization matrix is paramount important along with the expertise and machines & tooling required. People management of various behaviors and characters will also be discussed. | Communications leading to clear & concise information and instruction is crucial & critical for official and unofficial communication channels. With extensive ways of communications nowadays, project team need to discuss and evaluate for the benefit of project and stakeholders. The official channel has to be established upfront to avoid any haywire and overlapping thus separating the fake from the authentic.

The worst thing that can happen due to false data/information is REWORK which MUST be avoided as it surely affects all the PM Essentials, especially with the current technology like AI & IOT or AIOT. Individual Exercise for ROI and Break-Even Analysis.

module_title:
REVIEW OF DAY 1
DISCUSSION ON DAY 1: | PME 8: RISK | MORNING TEA BREAK
submodule_title:
Individual Exercise for ROI and Break-Even Analysis. | Project is fond and vulnerable to Risk. Correct and adequate Coverage is necessary to safeguard the project and company.
As example, Construction company will tend to carry out Construction Risk Assessment to identify the potential Risk from any kind of possible hazardous Materials, Acts or others related. Notwithstanding, proper coverage is needed sufficiently. 

Various types Risk can emerge from many aspects including from the Triple Constraint mentioned earlier i.e.;
1. Time has limits and cannot delay with EOT - Extension of Time forever
2. Cost to generate profit otherwise better still abandoned the project
3. Quality has to be complied for certification via ITP - Inspection Test Plan & Commissioning /Testing toward CCC or other relevant approval.
4. Otherwise, the Risk is to REWORK!!!

module_title: BOQ Procurement / Supply Chain for Global Network Sourcing | PM 8: RISK (CONTINUED) | PM 9: PROCUREMENT | LUNCH BREAK
submodule_title:
Risk coverage is available among others are;
1. Warranty / Guarantees
2. Performance Bond
3. Bank Guarantee
4. Professional Indemnity Insurance - PII | Procurement or Purchasing also known for some reason as Supply
Chain is critical to avoid excessive leading to unnecessarily loss. BOM and BOQ specialized tools which can be closely linked to WBS to control procurement wisely.
Some of the common prudent and economical techniques are;
1. pricing strategy
2. price hedging
3. future order, and
4. loyal supplier and networking

module_title: Module 1: Getting Familiar with Slide Layout and Section | Module 2: Working with the Notes Pane | MORNING TEA BREAK
submodule_title: Slide Layout are vital for making great presentations. Think of them as the backbone of your PowerPoint presentation.  | A clever location to add extra text to a slide that your audience will not see, but you can use as an aid when presenting or as printed handouts.

module_title: Module 3: Customizing Interface, Themes, Colors and Fonts | LUNCH BREAK
submodule_title:
• Topic A: Customizing the PowerPoint Interface
Find and add menu items and buttons that you frequently use to your ribbon or quick access toolbar to give you faster access to the PowerPoint features you probably use the most.
• Topic B: Changing Themes and Colors
Quickly change the colors, fonts, effects or design of your entire presentation in almost a single mouse click.

module_title: Module 4: Adding Text and Shapes | Module 5: Remove Picture Backgrounds | AFTERNOON TEA BREAK | Module 6: Infographics and Media
submodule_title:
• Topic A: The Content Placeholder and Bullet Levels
Use placeholders to quickly add content to your slides including text, diagrams, and charts – so that you can later change the location and proportions of these objects, often with a single mouse click.
• Topic B: Formatting Text
Format text in your presentation so that it is legible and perhaps even pleasant to look at!
• Topic C: Adding and Manipulating Shapes
Add and work with shapes, which are one of the most important building blocks on a slide, including rectangles, ovals, and triangles.
• Topic D: Duplicate and Add Multiple Shapes
Reuse existing, formatted shapes to save time inserting shape content on your slides.
• Topic E: Group and Ungroup Shapes
Group various shapes together into a single slide object to help you position the group of shapes in a specific location, while still gaining access to the size and formatting options available within PowerPoint for those individual shapes | Make the selected part of a picture transparent to either cleverly crop parts of the picture or make parts of the picture transparent to overlay in front of other pictures without obscuring them.
• Topic A: Remove Picture Background
Make the selected part of a picture transparent to either cleverly crop parts of the picture or make parts of the picture transparent to overlay in front of other pictures without obscuring them.
• Topic B: Photo Album
Quickly add multiple pictures to a presentation even in the format of two or four pictures per slide.
• Topic C: Edit Photo Album
Change the photo’s layout and design save as a slide show | • Topic A: Introducing SmartArt
Insert, add text to, and format SmartArt graphics to quickly add diagrams to your presentation which will assist you to tell your story.

module_title: Module 7: Numbers to Graphic & Mini Dashboard | Module 8: Structure Your Tables | MORNING TEA BREAK
submodule_title:
• Topic A: Adding and Editing Charts
Select the right chart for your data, add it to a slide, know the basics of editing charts and quickly format charts.
• Topic B: Advanced Chart Options
Understand and work with the tricky parts of charts such as axes and legends. Topic C: Mini Dashboard Create Mini Dashboard that link to Excel Data. | Add tabular data to your presentation in the form of a table and change the table’s appearance.

module_title: Module 9: Adding Audio | Module 10: Transition and Animation | LUNCH BREAK
submodule_title:
Insert sound on your slides so that your presentation can play music, narration or other sound effects.
• Topic A: Edit Video playback tool
Amend the video set it automatic play, trim the video, change the video.
• Topic B: Inserting Book Mark for animation
Insert video into your presentation and use various formatting options such as soft edges, or 3-D bevels to make your video really stand out.
• Topic C: Events and Speed
Make your animated objects speed up or slow down, or play with or without your intervention, depending on which you desire. Using Advance animation technics as trigger setting. | • Topic A: Motion Path Animations
Make an object move along a defined or custom path to enhance the engagement of your audience or explain in animated form very complex topics.
• Topic B: Transitions
Add smooth or exciting transitions between slides to increase the smoothness and continuity of your slideshow into an almost movie-like format.

module_title: Module 11: Duplicating and Reordering Slides | AFTERNOON TEA BREAK | Module 12: Delivering Your Presentation
submodule_title:
Reuse existing slides in your current presentation to save development time, as well is changing the order in which your slides play within a slideshow.
• Topic A: Reusing and Copying Slides
Reuse existing slides from another presentation and retain the theme of that presentation if you wish.
• Topic B: Working with Slide Sections
Group your slides into common concepts or thoughts to help build your storyline, as well is quickly move all the slides within that group to a new area of your presentation.
• Topic C: Reset – the Magic Button
When you work extensively on a chart, picture or slide and it doesn’t turn out exactly how you wish, quickly reset it back to what it was originally. | • Topic A: Printing Slides
Quickly print your slides professionally to give to your audience or create PDFs to distribute either before or after the slideshow.
• Topic B: Rehearsing Slides
“Practice makes perfect” – so rehearse your slides and practice the delivery of your presentation.
• Topic C: Exploring Slide Show Options
Before you present your slideshow, set your show up to present in a variety of ways with the confidence that little will go wrong.
• Topic D: Using Presenter View
Use a special PowerPoint view so that even though your audience can only see the slide show, you can view slide timings, slide notes and even a preview of the next, upcoming slide.
